title: 【肉酸到】奧巴馬話美國經濟好佢有功勞

replies.msg:
美國前總統奧巴馬指出, 美國經濟強勁並非現屆政府功勞.

奧巴馬在伊利諾伊大學講話時表示, 當他卸任總統時, 家庭收入接近歷史最高水平, 未有保險的國民比率, 達到歷史最低水平, 而貧窮率正在下降. 他提醒現屆政府, 當吹噓經濟實力時, 請記住美國這輪經濟復甦由何時開始.
對於美國的政治變化, 奧巴馬指出, 現任總統特朗普是一種症狀, 而不是原因. 特朗普只是利用政客過去多年一直煽動的仇恨, 而這種仇恨源於美國人過去的恐懼和憤怒, 以及源於美國人所經歷過的巨變.

他呼籲大學生, 在11月的國會中期選舉踴躍投票, 因為美國的民主取決於這次選舉結果. 他強調, 這次選舉比他人生中所記得的任何事情都更重要; 只要看看最近的頭條新聞, 就知道這次選舉事關重要, 若袖手旁觀的話, 後果會很可怕.

條死黑鬼之前先俾人踢爆佢用私怨拉左個鬧佢既導演，而家就仆出黎記係自己功勞

replies.msg:
https://www.brookings.edu/opinions/u-s-corporate-tax-reform-why-obamas-good-ideas-dont-add-up/

Obama has proposed repealing the right to defer U.S. corporate taxes on foreign profits. Under the current deferral system, U.S. multinationals have a powerful tax incentive to construct facilities and buy companies located outside the United States. If deferral were ended, these companies would make locational decisions based on business factors, rather than tax rates. Thus, a substantial portion of foreign profits of U.S. multinationals would likely be brought back to the United States to build plants, buy technologies and pay dividends.

Second, the budget would reduce the corporate tax rate from 35% to 28%. This is another sound idea because the United States currently has one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world, making it uncompetitive in a global economy. It’s true that reducing the tax rate to 28% would lower tax revenues by $840 billion over the next 10 years (the standard period for revenue estimates), but the budget suggests that this revenue loss can be offset by closing “loopholes” in the corporate tax code.

In fact, most large corporate tax preferences are aimed at promoting economic growth so they have strong bipartisan support. The tax preferences generating the largest revenue losses include the research and development tax credit, the special deduction for U.S. manufacturing, and accelerated depreciation for capital investments. Of course, there has been a lot of clamor about the favorable tax treatment of corporate jets, incentive fees for hedge fund managers, and generous allowances for drilling costs. But these much criticized “loopholes” amount to less than $100 billion in revenue losses over 10 years.
